intro: Leptothrix crinita, commonly known as the hairy filamentous bacterium, is a type of bacteria that forms long, slimy, gelatinous filaments. It is a member of the order Acidobacteriales and is known for its ability to produce a sheath-like structure around its filaments. This organism is often found in freshwater environments, such as lakes and streams, where it plays a role in nutrient cycling. Leptothrix crinita is notable for its unique morphology and its ability to form biofilms. Its presence can be an indicator of water quality and ecological conditions in aquatic ecosystems.
